title: x86-interrupt calling convention leads to wrong error code in debug mode

labels.name: A-LLVM
labels.description: Area: Code generation parts specific to LLVM. Both correctness bugs and optimization-related issues.

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
When using the [x86-interrupt calling convention](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/40180) for an exception with error code, the error code is wrong in debug mode. I checked the assembly code and it seems like it loads the first field of the exception stack frame instead of the error code, i.e. it is off by 8 bytes, so this seems to be a bug in LLVM. The interesting thing is that the error code is correct in release mode.

It worked correctly with nightly `(9389e23a8 2017-12-31)`, so it is a regression. I'm currently trying different Rust versions to find out when the problem was introduced:

Nightly | Works?
-----| ------
(9389e23a8 2017-12-31) | Yes
(8ccab7eed 2018-01-31) | Yes
(bd98fe0c0 2018-02-06) | Yes
(3bcda48a3 2018-02-09) | Yes
(45fba43b3 2018-02-10) | No
(b8398d947 2018-02-11) | No
(4d2d3fc5d 2018-02-13) | No
(0ff9872b2 2018-02-28) | No
(1ffb32147 2018-05-31) | No
(f4a421ee3 2018-12-13) | No

**Edit**: The problem was introduced between the 2018-02-09 and the 2018-02-10 nightly. These are the relevant commits: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/compare/3bcda48...45fba43. I think it was most likely the upgrade to LLVM 6 in https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/47828, which was [huge](https://github.com/rust-lang/llvm/compare/bc344d5bc23c61ff9baf82d268a0edf199933cc3...9f81beaf32608fbe1fe0f2a82f974e800e9d8c62).

See https://github.com/phil-opp/blog_os/issues/513 for more context.
